Award.AwardTitle: A Three-dimensional Model of Spinal Cord Growth and Repair in a Regeneration-competent Organism

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Spinal cord injury represents an incurable condition, usually leading to severe life-long disability in humans. Numerous therapeutic strategies developed thus far to improve structural regeneration have resulted in only modest improvements. An alternative strategy is provided by the study of organisms that can spontaneously regenerate central nervous tissue after injury, such as fish and salamanders. Understanding the biological mechanisms underlying spinal cord healing in such species provides novel translational opportunities for the identification of therapeutic targets to treat spinal cord injuries in humans. This project focuses on the theoretical study of one exemplary organism, the brown ghost knifefish Apteronotus leptorhynchus. The goal is to integrate the wealth of existing experimental data into a systems-level theoretical framework through mathematical and computational modeling. The resulting model will be used to uncover some of the rules governing normal spinal cord growth, as well as to determine the optimal conditions for structural and functional spinal cord regeneration. Moreover, this project will demonstrate the power of interdisciplinary approaches, in particular the use of tools developed by engineers and mathematicians for solving biological problems.

The cellular and molecular processes underlying the growth of spinal cord tissue and its regeneration after injury have been studied extensively from a biological perspective. However, few attempts have been made to integrate the resulting empirical data into a comprehensive theoretical framework through computational and/or mathematical modeling. As part of this project, such a model will be developed by using the knifefish Apteronotus leptorhynchus as one of the best-examined organisms capable of spontaneous regeneration after spinal cord injury. A hybrid, discrete-continuous approach will be employed, combining an agent-based framework at the cellular level with a dynamical systems framework at the molecular level. This study will lead to the development of what is likely to be the first computational model of the cellular and molecular phenomena underlying growth and repair in a regeneration-competent organism. It will lead to a comprehensive understanding of healing dynamics within the central nervous system, making it possible to define the conditions for optimal regeneration. The computational framework established as part of the project will provide extended opportunities for other researchers working on growth and regeneration mechanisms, including the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of spinal cord injuries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

In contrast to mammals, the spinal cord of bony fish continues to grow during adult life through the addition of new cells arising from intrinsic neural stem cells. This ability is closely related to the enormous potential of fish to generate neural tissue and to recover behavioral function after spinal cord injury. Whereas a fair amount of experimental data has been collected in regard of these two phenomena, little is known about the rules that govern (re-) growth of spinal cord tissue. In the grant-funded research, we addressed this issue by integrating, through computational and mathematical modeling, experimental cell biological data into a theoretical framework. Deciphering these rules in regeneration-competent organisms, such as fish, is likely to lead to a better understanding of how spinal cord tissue could be regrown in human after injury.

Simulations based on our models indicated that, among other parameters, contact inhibition of proliferation of adult neural stem cells and their progenitors plays a major role in tissue development. At high densities of cells, this mechanism may even lead to complete suppression of mitotic division, despite persisting proliferative potential of the stem/progenitor cells. On the other hand, cell death of some of the newly generated cells, followed by clearance of their corpses through a mechanisms known as phagocytosis, was predicted to reduce contact inhibition, thereby increasing the probability of cell division (Sipahi and Zupanc, 2018; Lehotzky et al., 2021). These results suggest that, contrary to the traditional view of cell death as a rather passive mechanism for removal of supernumerary cells during development, dying cells may also assume a more active role in sculpting and growth of tissue, by remodeling of their cellular neighborhood through mechanical forces.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The broader impacts of the funded work, as defined by the merit criteria of the National Science Foundation, were addressed by a variety of activities, including the following major accomplishment.

Although the primary goal of our research was to study growth of central nervous system tissue as part of normal development and of regenerative processes after injury, our work also demonstrated significant potential of the constructed models for simulation of abnormal tissue growth after formation of tumors. By employing this approach, we were able to provide, for the first time, a theoretical explanation for a seemingly paradoxical observation made in clinical studies: that anti-cancer therapies based on induction of cell death may, in some instances, promote the development of tumorous tissue, instead of suppressing tumor growth (Zupanc et al., 2019).

In addition, the results of our research indicated that our mathematical and computational models can be used for making predictions about growth dynamics of biological tissue, including alterations of the dynamics and the final properties of tissue induced by experimental and medical interventions. Modified versions of such models could enable scientists in pharma and biotech industry to make better-informed decisions about experimental outcomes than is currently possible, thereby accelerating preclinical research, reducing the risk of failure, and saving money. To this end, we developed a prototype of a commercial modeling and simulation platform; filed a patent application in the United States Patent and Trademark Office; and conducted over one hundred interviews with potential customers to determine product-market fit. The latter activity was supported by an NSF I-Corps Teams grant directly related to this grant.

Throughout the grant period, we promoted teaching, training, and learning. At the same time, our activities in the area of education aimed at broadening participation of under-represented groups, such as women and minorities. Through engagement in the grant-funded research, we trained a total of three postdoctoral researchers (all males), two graduate students (one male, one female), and eleven undergraduate students (five males, six females including one from an under-represented ethnic group). Six of the undergraduates received for their research projects a total of eight awards, including five Advanced Research/Creative Endeavor Awards, one Honors Early Research Award, one Dr. Andrew I. Schafer Researcher Co-op Scholarship, and one PEAK Experiences Trailblazer Award (the latter is the highest undergraduate research recognition awarded by Northeastern University). Undergraduates researchers co-authored papers published (three students) or prepared for publication (one student) in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

We also created several educational resources and made them freely available to the community. They include: a web-based interactive simulator for simulating stem-cell-driven tissue growth in teaching labs (http://neurosphere.cos.northeastern.edu/); and three papers that describe educational lab activities at the interface of biology, physics, engineering, and computer science (Zupanc, 2016, 2019; Zupanc et al., 2021). One of these articles (Zupanc, 2016) received wide international recognition by being published in five translations (German, Greek, Hungarian, Romanian, and Spanish), in addition to its original English version.
